a.span: Astonishing performance from a 2 core chip!

div.div:
For an 2 core chip, this is really performing astonishingly well. Without overclocking either chip, the i3's Passmark performance test is coming up at 93% of the score of an i5-3570k and costs $79 less. I partially upgraded an old workstation for our graphic designer with this, 16gb of ram and a Z97 micro ATX mobo and her productivity has been substantially increased.
I would heartily recommend this chip for anybody looking to do a budget performance build.

div.span: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful

div.div:
Writing this review on a computer powered by this CPU.
Installation was easy, I purchased additional thermal paste but didn't need to use it.
CPU temperature right now is 34 degrees celcius, that's about slightly lower than body temperature. So if I could touch it now, it would actually feel cold! Fan speed 1580 RPM. I've been using the computer for a couple of hours now.
When I play games, the temperature never rises above 60 degrees celcius.
I purchased it for Skyrim and Bioshock Infinite, and they run butter smooth - even when I am recording hires videos of the games.
Am happy about the CPU.

div.div: Fast for a dual core. I get a WEI score of 7.6 for processor with 8GB of RAM. Stays cool with an idle temp of 30 degree C in the living room at 72 F. The process score is higher the the 7.5 of my I7-2820QM 2.3/3.4 four core 16GB laptop. The 4600 GPU portion runs 1080P video with no audio/video drops. Unless you need to run high end games, no dedicated GPU is necessary.

a.span: It seems to do as good of a job for the most part as the ...

div.div: Should have bought (4) when the were $122 from Amazon. I am comparing this against both the stock and clocked pentium K g3258, and i5-4760k, across Gigabytes z87x-ud5h, h81, h85, z97 gaming 5, and h97 gaming 3. For the price, the pentium K works for what it is, but it fails at multitasking, the high base clock, GPU, + cache + hyperthreading truely makes this chip greater than 1/2 a quad core, in running multiple programs and tasking. It seems to do as good of a job for the most part as the i5-4670k, with exception, e.g. data intensive tasks, encrypting files video editing, raring files extracting compressing etc., however, I have that processor in another machine for those tasks I don't need it sitting idle running most of the day twiddling it's thumbs, at replacement cost of nearly double. Plus when doing extensive quad-core tasking as mentioned functional use of your PC can be hindered or may cause crashing, potentially losing other work, I would rather have a PC for each purpose, in which each integral component serves it's specific task without over or under working itself or other parts.

a.span: Great processor with a great performance to price ratio

div.div: Great processor with a great performance to price ratio. This is not used for gaming, just light office and home computing. I built two identical systems with this, one for parents and one for my sister. One of them is working great, the other seems to have overheated and is returning video errors, resulting in blank screen and driver recoveries. I discovered that it was because the computer was placed in area with very little airflow, and must have been damaged by overheating. I installed a better heat sink (originally just used the stock heat sink) and it seems to have improved significantly, though it looks like the processor is now permanently damaged. It isn't returning many driver errors anymore, and isn't overheating anymore. Just a word of caution from someone who should have known better than to trust a stock heat sink and fan. Buy an aftermarket fan and heat sink for peace of mind, especially if you plan to put the computer in an area with restricted airflow around the case.
